threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the execution of a Windows system binary that is usually located in the system folder from an uncommon location.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Patrick Bareiss, Anton Kutepov, oscd.community, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Execution of Powershell Script in Public Folder
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: This rule detects execution of PowerShell scripts located in the "C:\Users\Public" folder
Detects usage of the "FromBase64String" function in the commandline which is used to decode a base64 encoded string

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Change PowerShell Policies to an Insecure Level
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects changing the PowerShell script execution policy to a potentially insecure level using the "-ExecutionPolicy" flag.

Adversaries may use hidden windows to conceal malicious activity from the plain sight of users.
In some cases, windows that would typically be displayed when an application carries out an operation can be hidden

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets - ScriptBlock
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via PowerShell scriptblock logs
Detects non-interactive PowerShell activity by looking at the "powershell" process with a non-user GUI process such as "explorer.exe" as a parent.

attributes.magic: ASCII text, with very long lines (3152u)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature fires on the presence of Base64 encoded URI prefixes (http:// and https://) across any file. The simple presence of such strings is not inherently an indicator of malicious content, but is worth further investigation.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects base64 encoded Powershell directives.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert icmp $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any ( msg:"PROTOCOL-ICMP Unusual PING detected"; icode:0; itype:8; fragbits:!M; content:!"ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWABCDEFGHI",depth 32; content:!"0123456789abcdefghijklmnopqrstuv",depth 32; content:!"EEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE",depth 36; content:!"WANG2"; content:!"cacti-monitoring-system",depth 65; content:!"SolarWinds",depth 72; metadata:policy max-detect-ips drop,ruleset community; reference:url,krebsonsecurity.com/2014/01/a-closer-look-at-the-target-malware-part-ii/; reference:url,krebsonsecurity.com/2014/01/a-first-look-at-the-target-intrusion-malware/; classtype:successful-recon-limited; sid:29456; rev:3; )

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET INFO HTTP Request to a *.top domain
ET DNS Query to a *.top domain - Likely Hostile
ET INFO Windows Powershell User-Agent Usage

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert icmp $EXTERNAL_NET any -> $HOME_NET any ( msg:"PROTOCOL-ICMP PING Windows"; itype:8; content:"abcdefghijklmnop",depth 16; metadata:ruleset community; classtype:misc-activity; sid:382; rev:11; )
alert icmp $EXTERNAL_NET any -> $HOME_NET any ( msg:"PROTOCOL-ICMP PING"; icode:0; itype:8; metadata:ruleset community; classtype:misc-activity; sid:384; rev:8; )
alert icmp $EXTERNAL_NET any -> $HOME_NET any ( msg:"PROTOCOL-ICMP Echo Reply"; icode:0; itype:0; metadata:ruleset community; classtype:misc-activity; sid:408; rev:8; )

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis: The code snippet is a VBScript that performs several actions.  It begins with a 15-second sleep.  It then constructs a string "Wscript.Shell" and creates an object of this type.  Several variables are declared, but their contents are not readily discernible due to obfuscation.  A substantial portion of the code consists of long strings of seemingly random words; the significance of these strings is unknown.  The code retrieves the current hour and minute.  There is an obfuscated section of code that appears to perform calculations based on the current time. It creates two text files named "vPOx6Cyn.ps1" and "vPOx6Cyn.bat" in the %APPDATA% directory.  The content written to "vPOx6Cyn.ps1" is base64 encoded and contains what appears to be PowerShell commands. The "vPOx6Cyn.bat" file contains commands to execute the "vPOx6Cyn.ps1" script via PowerShell. The script then executes the ".bat" file.  A file is also created in the user's Downloads folder, named after the script itself, but with the ".docx" extension. The script checks if the original script file exists and not in the Temp directory, and if so deletes it.
